question: Is Iron deficiency anemia a common complication of chronic kidney disease?
ideal_answer: iron deficiency anemia is common in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).

snippets.text: Intravenous iron therapy is increasingly being used worldwide to treat anemia in chronic kidney disease and more recently iron deficiency in heart failure.

Anemia resulting from iron and erythropoietin deficiencies is a common complication of advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD).
Iron deficiency is common in individuals with chronic kidney disease and plays a major role in the development of anemia.
Iron deficiency anemia is a common occurrence in patients with chronic kidney disease and many patients do not respond well to supplementation with oral iron.

However, the diagnosis of iron-deficiency anemia in CKD patients is complicated by the relatively poor predictive ability of easily obtained routine serum iron indices (eg, ferritin and transferrin saturation) and more invasive gold standard measures of iron deficiency (eg, bone marrow iron stores) or erythropoietic response to supplemental iron.

Limited data suggest that iron deficiency is common in patients with chronic kidney disease with anemia; this lack of iron can hinder the effectiveness of erythropoiesis.
